qas.question: What do monocots usually have two of within each seed?

plausible_answers.text: neither a particularly handy nor a reliable character

qas.question: According to the Cronquist system how is the number of cotyledons viewed?

plausible_answers.text: Dicotyledones or Dicotyledoneae, and Monocotyledones or Monocotyledoneae

qas.question: What other descriptive names are allowed by the English system?
How many groups are flowering plants divided into in the English system?
What is one group that is used under the English system?

context: Traditionally, the flowering plants are divided into <b3_0>two<b3_0/> groups, which in the Cronquist system are called <b4_0>Magnoliopsida<b4_0/> (at the rank of class, formed from the family name Magnoliaceae) and Liliopsida (at the rank of class, formed from the family name Liliaceae). Other descriptive names allowed by Article 16 of the ICBN include <b2_0>Dicotyledones or Dicotyledoneae, and Monocotyledones or Monocotyledoneae<b2_0/>, which have a long history of use. In English a member of either group may be called a dicotyledon (plural dicotyledons) and monocotyledon (plural monocotyledons), or abbreviated, as dicot (plural dicots) and monocot (plural monocots). These names derive from the observation that the dicots most often have two <b0_0>cotyledons<b0_0/>, or embryonic leaves, within each seed. The monocots usually have only one, but the rule is not absolute either way. From a diagnostic point of view, the number of cotyledons is <b1_0>neither a particularly handy nor a reliable character<b1_0/>.
